ã€ŒSF-PLFã€13 References

Programming Language Foundations - Typing Mutable References

Posted by Hux on March 13, 2019

Hux: this chapter is very similar to TAPL - ch13 References But under a â€œformal verificationâ€ concept, itâ€™s more interesting and practical and push you to think about it!

computational effects - â€œside effectsâ€ of computation - impure features

  • assign to mutable variables (reference cells, arrays, mutable record fields, etc.)
  • perform input and output to files, displays, or network connections;
  • make non-local transfers of control via exceptions, jumps, or continuations;
  • engage in inter-process synchronization and communication

The main extension will be dealing explicitly with a

  • store (or heap) and
  • pointers (or reference) that name store locations, or addressâ€¦

interesting refinement: type preservation

Definition

forms of assignments:

  • rare : Gallina - No
  • some : ML family - Explicit reference and dereference
  • most : C family - Implicit â€¦

For formal study, use MLâ€™s model.

T ::= 
    | Nat
    | Unit
    | T â†’ T
    | Ref T

t ::= 
    | ...                Terms
    | ref t              allocation
    | !t                 dereference
    | t := t             assignment
    | l                  location

Inductive ty : Type :=
  | Nat : ty
  | Unit : ty
  | Arrow : ty â†’ ty â†’ ty
  | Ref : ty â†’ ty.

Inductive tm : Type :=
  (* STLC with numbers: *)
  ...
  (* New terms: *)
  | unit : tm
  | ref : tm â†’ tm
  | deref : tm â†’ tm
  | assign : tm â†’ tm â†’ tm
  | loc : nat â†’ tm.         (** è¿™é‡Œè¡¨ç¤º l çš„æ–¹å¼æ˜¯ wrap ä¸€ä¸ª nat as loc **)

Typing

1

12

                       Gamma |- t1 : T1
                   ------------------------                         (T_Ref)
                   Gamma |- ref t1 : Ref T1

                    Gamma |- t1 : Ref T11
                    ---------------------                         (T_Deref)
                      Gamma |- !t1 : T11

                    Gamma |- t1 : Ref T11
                      Gamma |- t2 : T11
                   ------------------------                      (T_Assign)
                   Gamma |- t1 := t2 : Unit

Values and Substitution

1

3
4

Inductive value : tm â†’ Prop :=
  ...
  | v_unit :     value unit
  | v_loc  : âˆ€l, value (loc l).  (* <-- æ³¨æ„è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª Î  (l:nat) . value (loc l) *)

1

8
9

Fixpoint subst (x:string) (s:tm) (t:tm) : tm :=
  match t with
  ...
  | unit         â‡’ t
  | ref t1       â‡’ ref (subst x s t1)
  | deref t1     â‡’ deref (subst x s t1)
  | assign t1 t2 â‡’ assign (subst x s t1) (subst x s t2)
  | loc _        â‡’ t
  end.

Pragmatics

Side Effects and Sequencing

1

r:=succ(!r); !r

can be desugar to

1

(\x:Unit. !r) (r:=succ(!r)).

then we can write some â€œimperative programmingâ€

1
2
3
4

r:=succ(!r); 
r:=succ(!r); 
r:=succ(!r); 
!r

References and Aliasing

shared reference brings _shared state

1
2
3
4

let r = ref 5 in
let s = r in
s := 82;
(!r)+1

Shared State

thunks as methods

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
9

    let c = ref 0 in
    let incc = \_:Unit. (c := succ (!c); !c) in
    let decc = \_:Unit. (c := pred (!c); !c) in (
      incc unit; 
      incc unit;          -- in real PL: the concrete syntax is `incc()`
      decc unit
    )

Objects

constructor and encapsulation!

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
9

    newcounter =
      \_:Unit.            -- add `(self, init_val)` would make it more "real"
        let c = ref 0 in  -- private and only accessible via closure (ç‰¹æƒæ–¹æ³•)
        let incc = \_:Unit. (c := succ (!c); !c) in
        let decc = \_:Unit. (c := pred (!c); !c) in
        { i=incc, 
          d=decc  }       -- return a "record", or "struct", or "object"!

References to Compound Types (e.g. Function Type)

Previously, we use closure to represent map, with functional update è¿™é‡Œçš„â€æ•°ç»„â€ ï¼ˆè¿™ä¸ªåˆ°åº•ç®—ä¸ç®—æ•°ç»„ä¼°è®¡éƒ½æœ‰äº‰è®®ï¼Œè™½ç„¶çš„ç¡®æä¾›äº† index ä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªæ˜¾ç„¶æ˜¯ O(n) éƒ½ä¸çŸ¥é“ç®—ä¸ç®— random accessâ€¦ å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯ in-place update é‡Œé¢çš„æ•°æ®çš„ï¼Œä»…ä»…æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª ref åŒ…ä½çš„ map è€Œå·² ï¼ˆä»…ä»…æ˜¯å¤šäº†å¯ä»¥ shared

å…¶å®æˆ–è®¸ list (ref nat) ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è¡¨è¾¾æ•°ç»„ï¼Ÿ åæ­£éƒ½æ˜¯ O(n) æ¯æ¬¡éƒ½ linear search ä¹Ÿä¸€æ ·â€¦â€¦

    newarray = \_:Unit. ref (\n:Nat.0)
    lookup = \a:NatArray. \n:Nat. (!a) n   
    update = \a:NatArray. \m:Nat. \v:Nat.
               let oldf = !a in
               a := (\n:Nat. if equal m n then v else oldf n);

Null References

nullptr!

Deref a nullptr:

  • exception in Java/C#
  • insecure in C/C++ <â€“ violate memory safety!!
1
2
3
4

    type Option T   = Unit + T
    type Nullable T = Option (Ref T)

Why is Option outside? think about C, nullptr is A special const location, like Unit (None in terms of datacon) here.

Garbage Collection

last issue: store de-allocation

w/o GC, extremely difficult to achieve type safetyâ€¦if a primitive for â€œexplicit deallocationâ€ provided one can easily create dangling reference i.e. references -> deleted

One type-unsafe example: (pseudo code)

1
2
3
4
5
6
7

   a : Ref Nat = ref 1;       -- alloc loc 0
   free(a);                   -- free  loc 0
   b : Ref Bool = ref True;   -- alloc loc 0
   
   a := !a + 1                -- BOOM!

Operational Semantics

Locations

what should be the values of type Ref T?

ref allocate some memory/storage!

run-time store is essentially big array of bytes. different datatype need to allocate different size of space (region)

we think store as array of values, abstracting away different size of different values we use the word location here to prevent from modeling pointer arithmetic, which is un-trackable by most type system

location n is float doesnâ€™t tell you anything about location n+4â€¦

Stores

we defined replace as Fixpoint since itâ€™s computational and easier. The consequence is it has to be total.

Typing

typing context:

1

Definition context := partial_map ty.

Store typings

why not just make a context a map of pair? we donâ€™t want to complicate the dynamics of language, and this store typing is only for type check.
